# Draft:Mutawakkilite-Idrisid War

----
The Idrisi–Mutawakkilite Wars were a series of military confrontations between the Idrisi Emirate of Asir and the Mutawakkilite Kingdom of Yemen during the early 20th century. The conflicts reshaped power in southern Arabia and culminated in the decline of Idrisi influence.
Background
The Idrisi Emirate, founded by Muhammad ibn Ali al-Idrisi in 1906, emerged from Ottoman withdrawal and gained British backing to counter Ottoman and Saudi expansion.
Imam Yahya sought to unify Yemen historically from Asir to Dhofar and resist foreign encroachment.
Course of the war
Despite British military support, the Idrisis never secured a battlefield victory. Ameen Rihani states that “the Idrisis and their British allies did not win a single battle against the Mutawakkilites.”
Imam Yahya's forces advanced into Asir, besieging Aden’s walls and reaching Ṣabiyā.
The British seized al-Hudaydah and handed it to the Idrisis to reinforce them. This provoked Imam Yahya, who retook the port and clashed with British forces.
The fragmented Idrisi leadership offered a political union under Imam Yahya, but he refused, citing their Moroccan origin and labeling them non-Arab intruders to be expelled.
Outcome
Imam Yahya achieved a decisive victory. The Idrisi Emirate lost autonomy and later came under Saudi control. British attempts to project power via the Idrisis failed.
Legacy
These wars ended the Idrisis as a regional force and underscored the limits of British influence in the Arabian hinterland.
References
* Anne K. Bang, The Idrisi State of Asir 1906–1934: Politics, Religion and Personal Prestige as State-building factors in early twentieth century Arabia, Hurst, 1996.
* John Baldry, "Anglo-Italian Rivalry in Yemen and ʿAsīr 1900–1934", Die Welt des Islams, 1976.
* G. F. Al-Etaneh, R. Hayajneh, J. M. Al-Khatib & A. A. Abdalla, “British-Idrisi relations in resisting Ottoman influence in Tihama Asir 1915–1926”, Research Journal in Advanced Humanities, Vol. 5 No. 4, 2024.
